content.webTitle: England’s Tottenham contingent show no sign of fatigue, says Harry Kane

fields.headline: England’s Tottenham contingent show no sign of fatigue, says Harry Kane
fields.bodyText: One golden boot won, another to go. That is the ambition for Harry Kane, who has barely stopped scoring since his remarkable breakthrough last year, as he approaches the final weeks of a campaign that ended in disappointment at Tottenham Hotspur but could yet finish with a summer to remember with England. Kane, Dele Alli, Eric Dier, Kyle Walker and Danny Rose were not the ones who arrived at St George’s Park this week with Premier League winner’s medals. Leicester’s players, not Tottenham’s, had that honour and Kane was one of the first to congratulate Jamie Vardy and Danny Drinkwater on their season of seasons. It is the Spurs striker, though, who is expected to lead the line for England at the European Championship in France. This time last year Kane was in the Czech Republic with the under-21s after a stunning end-of-season run at Tottenham and, despite a brief period when the goals slowed up on his return, there have been few signs of personal fatigue, even though questions have been asked about Mauricio Pochettino’s intense training regime and its effect on Spurs’ last few performances. Kane rejected suggestions of heavy legs within the Tottenham contingent of Roy Hodgson’s squad before Sunday’s friendly with Turkey at the Etihad Stadium, coming before other England warm-up games against Australia and Portugal. Instead, Kane says, the squad is vibrant and fearless. “For a lot of us it’s our first major tournament,” he said. “There’s no real fear – we are not scared to play our football. Throughout the whole international year we’ve been playing well, we’ve been going out and trying to play good football, we’ve been scoring goals, pressing high. That’s what the manager wants us to do and that’s what we’ll try to do. “There’s been some disappointments over the years but now we’ve got a great young side, we’re very excited about the tournament and we’ve got no fear. We’ll go out, play our football and express ourselves and see where that takes us.” Asked about Pochettino’s teams potentially tiring at the end of a season, Kane said: “I don’t really believe that. Obviously, we didn’t get the performances we wanted in the last four or five weeks but we were still running, still pressing high but things probably just got in our way. “We put so much energy into fighting for the title and the race, maybe it might have had a little psychological effect but that’s something we’re going to get better at. I know the manager spoke about that – getting a better mentality. Hopefully it’s something that we can learn from and get better at. “But we’re all still feeling good. There’s not been one complaint or anybody moaning that they were tired. We’re here and we’re excited to get going. I feel very good, I feel fit and ready to go. I’ve kept myself in good shape, had a good recovery and I think that’s important.” Kane is one of five forwards Hodgson named in his provisional 26-man squad on Monday. Wayne Rooney, Daniel Sturridge and Vardy were not surprise selections but it was the name of Marcus Rashford that caught the eye and Hodgson has challenged the young Manchester United striker to knock one of the established names “off their perch” and make the cut for the final 23 who will go to France. Rashford has made the most of his chance at United since being given his debut because of an injury in the warm-up to Anthony Martial before a Europa League game, and although Kane has yet to properly meet the 18-year-old, he is expecting fireworks when Rashford links up with the squad. “He’s been outstanding,” Kane said. “Full credit to him, he deserves his place. He’s young, he’s come in and shown no fear of playing on the big stage and he’s just expressed himself. He’s not been fazed by playing in the Premier League and hopefully he can take that on to the international stage. We are looking forward to meeting him when he reports next week, seeing his ability. He’s shown at the back end of the season that he can score goals and he’s a real talent. “Obviously we [Tottenham] played against United a month or two ago now and shook his hand but I never really got into a conversation with him. But it will be good to meet him next week and see what he’s like as a person, and as a player. If you’re playing for England you’re going to have threats for your position. We’re all fighting for our position – no one is secure or a definite starter, so we go from now up to the Euros trying to cement our place.” Kane believes England’s performance in Germany two months ago, when Hodgson’s team overturned a deficit to win 3-2, is evidence of their potential. Kane, who scored 25 goals in the Premier League in the season just finished, has proven himself at club level. Next up is a sterner examination. “That’d be nice,” he said, when asked if he was targeting the Euro 2016 golden boot. “That’s the aim, definitely. The more the merrier. The whole team are very excited. Now the season is over we’re itching to get out there, to see what it’s like and get going.”
